study_duration: Not specified for in vitro assays; apoptosis observed after 48 hours of treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Terminalia Chebula (TCR) could protect against cardiotoxicity induced by Aconitum kusnezoffii Reichb (AKR).
results_summary: TCR reduced AKR-induced cardiotoxicity, as evidenced by lower serum myoglobin (MB) and troponin (cTn) levels, improved histopathological outcomes, and reversal of metabolomic changes. The detoxifying effect was most pronounced in the TCR-prepared AKR and AKR-TCR 1:1 groups.
population_specificity: Not specified (animal or human study not explicitly stated, but likely animal model based on methodology).
effective_dosage: AKR-TCR ratios of 1:3, 1:1, and 3:1 (exact amounts not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antibacterial and antioxidant effects of Terminalia chebula ethanol extract (EETC) on Streptococcus mutans and its potential application in oral hygiene products for dental caries management.
results_summary: EETC demonstrated antibacterial activity against S. mutans, reduced glucan formation, and downregulated genes involved in biofilm formation. It also showed antioxidant activity and was non-cytotoxic to gingival fibroblasts.
population_specificity: In vitro study (bacterial cultures and human gingival fibroblasts).
effective_dosage: Not specified (MIC and MBC values determined but exact dosages not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the main bioactive compounds in Terminalia chebula var. tomentella (TCT) fruits and evaluate their anti-inflammatory and hypoglycemic activities.
results_summary: The study identified 14 compounds in TCT fruits, including a new hydrolyzable tannin, with several showing strong NO inhibitory (anti-inflammatory) and α-glucosidase inhibitory (hypoglycemic) effects, outperforming positive controls.
population_specificity: In vitro (RAW264.7 cells) and molecular docking studies; no human or animal subjects specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the preventive effect of a Terminalia chebula and Zingiber officinale extract (ZOTC) against DMBA-induced breast cancer in rats, focusing on the mTOR pathway.
results_summary: ZOTC improved antioxidant status, serum lipid levels, and cytokines, and downregulated mTOR expression, suggesting it suppresses tumor progression in DMBA-induced breast cancer rats.
population_specificity: Female rats with DMBA-induced mammary carcinogenesis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Terminalia Chebula extract (TWE) could protect against Aβ1-42-induced toxicity and aggregation in a C. elegans model of Alzheimer's disease (AD).
results_summary: TWE significantly reduced Aβ-induced paralysis (up to 14%) and inhibited Aβ aggregation (up to 70%) in transgenic C. elegans, likely through activation of the DAF-16/HSF-1/Hsp-16.2 pathway. No improvement was observed in SKN-1-deficient worms, suggesting pathway specificity.
population_specificity: Transgenic Caenorhabditis elegans (C. elegans) strains CL2006 and CL4176, modeling Aβ toxicity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the molecular mechanism of gallic acid from Terminalia chebula in suppressing the growth of esophageal carcinoma.
results_summary: Gallic acid decreased cell viability and colony formation, promoted apoptosis in esophageal carcinoma cells, and reduced tumor growth in mice by blocking the Hippo pathway. The effects were concentration-dependent, with notable results at 0.3% GA.
population_specificity: Human esophageal carcinoma cells (EC9706 and KYSE450) and EC mice.
effective_dosage: 10, 20, and 40 μg/ml in vitro; 0.3% and 1% GA in vivo.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to profile dermal expression responses to a standardized tannin-enriched Terminalia chebula (TC) fruit extract and elucidate its molecular and cellular mechanisms in skin health.
results_summary: TC extract reversed gene expression patterns associated with oxidative stress, UV radiation, and wounding, enhancing skin barrier function, extracellular matrix components, and keratinocyte differentiation markers. It also inhibited MMP enzymes and microbial activity, suggesting potential benefits for skin aging and wound healing.
population_specificity: Three-dimensional reconstituted human skin cultures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate Terminalia chebula's long-lasting antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties and its ability to reverse pollution-induced skin damage.
results_summary: The standardized TC fruit extract demonstrated superior ROS neutralization compared to tocopherol, reduced inflammatory cytokines, and protected against lipid peroxidation. Clinical results showed significant improvements in skin texture, hydration, tone, firmness, and radiance compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Subjects with normal to dry skin living in a high-pollution city for the previous 5 years.
effective_dosage: 1% standardized TC fruit extract (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the eco-friendly synthesis of silver nanoparticles (AgNPs) using Terminalia chebula fruit extract (TCE) and assess their antibacterial and anti-breast cancer potentials.
results_summary: The study found that AgNPs synthesized using TCE exhibited enhanced antibacterial activity (most effective against B. subtilis and P. aeruginosa) and anti-breast cancer effects (lowest IC50 for TCE + AgNPs combination). The spherical AgNPs had an average diameter of 22 nm.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on bacterial strains and MCF-7 breast cancer cells).
effective_dosage: IC50 values: TCE (17.53 µg/mL), AgNPs (14.25 µg/mL), TCE + AgNPs (6.484 µg/mL).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the inhibition of quorum sensing in Pseudomonas aeruginosa by Terminalia chebula ethanol extract and its effect on virulence factors.
results_summary: Terminalia chebula ethanol extract effectively repressed Las R expression, reducing virulence factors like biofilm formation, pyocyanin production, and motility. It also showed biocompatibility in zebrafish models without toxicity or hemolysis.
population_specificity: Pseudomonas aeruginosa isolated from a postoperative patient and zebrafish models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anticancer and anti-inflammatory activities of Terminalia chebula fruit extract (TCME) on lung (A549) and breast (MCF-7) cancer cell lines, as well as its anti-inflammatory effects on RAW 264.7 cells.
results_summary: TCME demonstrated cytotoxicity against A549 and MCF-7 cells, induced apoptosis via caspase-cascade pathways, and exhibited anti-inflammatory effects by regulating nitrite, TNF-α, iNOS, COX-2, and NF-κB. HPLC analysis identified bioactive phytocompounds in TCME.
population_specificity: In vitro study using A549 (lung cancer), MCF-7 (breast cancer), and RAW 264.7 (macrophage) cell lines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cytotoxicity and apoptotic activity of Terminalia chebula (TC) alone and in combination with Zingiber officinale (ZO) against breast cancer cells.
results_summary: Terminalia chebula demonstrated cytotoxic and apoptotic effects, reducing mitochondrial membrane potential, increasing reactive oxygen species, and downregulating mTOR and hTERT gene expression. The combination with ZO (1:4 ratio) showed enhanced efficacy with an IC50 of 53.5 μg/mL.
population_specificity: Breast cancer cells (in vitro study)
effective_dosage: IC50 of 108.5 μg/mL for TC alone

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Terminalia Chebula on endothelial dysfunction and oxidative stress biomarkers in type 2 diabetic patients.
results_summary: Terminalia Chebula (250 mg and 500 mg doses) significantly improved endothelial function and reduced cardiovascular risk indicators compared to placebo, with the 500 mg dose showing greater efficacy.
population_specificity: Type 2 diabetic patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antidiabetic potential of Terminalia chebula (TC) alone and in combination with Zingiber officinale (ZO) by assessing their effects on blood glucose, insulin levels, and pancreatic β cell function via mTOR downregulation.
results_summary: The study found that TC alone and in combination with ZO (ZOTC, 1:4 ratio) significantly reduced blood glucose levels, improved insulin sensitivity, and enhanced pancreatic β cell function in diabetic rats. The combination also showed antioxidant benefits without adverse effects on liver or serum parameters.
population_specificity: Fructose-streptozotocin (STZ)-induced diabetic rats.
effective_dosage: Not specified (only the 1:4 ratio of ZOTC was mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-diabetic, antioxidant, and hypolipidemic effects of a herbal combination including Terminalia chebula in STZ-induced diabetic rats.
results_summary: The study found that Terminalia chebula, in combination with other herbs, significantly improved blood glucose, lipid profile, and antioxidant markers in diabetic rats, with effects comparable to metformin. The highest dose showed the most pronounced benefits.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats with STZ-induced diabetes.
effective_dosage: 857 mg/kg, 642 mg/kg, and 1714 mg/kg of Terminalia chebula (hydro-ethanolic extract) in combination with other herbs.

study_goal: To evaluate and compare the clinical and radiographical success of Terminalia chebula gel as a pulpotomy medicament in primary teeth.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in efficacy between Terminalia chebula gel, Myristica fragrans gel, and Formocresol over a 12-month follow-up, suggesting comparable effectiveness as pulpotomy agents.
population_specificity: 20 children with at least two primary molars requiring pulpotomy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the acute and sub-acute toxic effects of Terminalia chebula extract in a murine model to establish safe dosage levels.
results_summary: The study found that Terminalia chebula had a safe acute dose of ≤5000 mg/kg, with an LD50 of 2754.436 mg/kg in the sub-acute phase. The highest dose induced minor histopathological changes in tissues.
population_specificity: Murine model (mice)
effective_dosage: Acute phase: ≤5000 mg/kg; Sub-acute phase: LD50 2754.436 mg/kg

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a hydrolysable tannin-rich fraction (HTF) from Terminalia chebula fruits in treating collagen-induced arthritis in mice.
results_summary: HTF significantly reduced paw volume, arthritic score, spleen index, serum and joint cytokine levels, and biochemical markers, demonstrating anti-inflammatory effects through cytokine inhibition. The results were supported by morphological, histopathological, and radiological evaluations.
population_specificity: BALB/c mice with collagen-induced arthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the hepatoprotective mechanism of chebulic acid (from Terminalia Chebula) against oxidative stress induced by tert-butyl hydroperoxide (t-BHP) in liver cells.
results_summary: Chebulic acid reduced cell death in t-BHP-induced HepG2 liver cells, increased glutathione content, upregulated heme oxygenase-1 activity, and enhanced Nrf2 nuclear translocation and target gene expression in a dose-dependent manner. It also activated mitogen-activated protein kinases, demonstrating a cytoprotective effect against hepatotoxicity.
population_specificity: HepG2 liver cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the in vivo and in vitro effects of methyl gallate (MG) from Terminalia chebula on fluid accumulation, bacterial colonization, inflammation, and biofilm formation in multi-drug resistant Vibrio cholerae infections.
results_summary: MG demonstrated significant fluid accumulation-inhibitory (42.86-89.08% inhibition), anticolonization, and anti-inflammatory effects in mice, along with biofilm-inhibitory and bacterial membrane-damaging activities at specific concentrations.
population_specificity: 4-5 day old BALB/c mice and Swiss albino mice.
study_duration: 18 hours (fluid accumulation/colonization), duration for inflammation not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anxiolytic activity of Terminalia chebula tannin-rich extract against picrotoxin-induced anxiety in mice and explore its potential mechanisms.
results_summary: Terminalia chebula extract increased locomotion, time in illuminated areas, and shock tolerance while down-regulating cortisol and up-regulating neurotransmitters (5-HT, DA, NE) and gene expressions (BDNF, CREB, GABA, 5-HT1A). It demonstrated significant anxiolytic effects against picrotoxin-induced anxiety.
population_specificity: Mice (animal model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-inflammatory and antioxidant effects of Terminalia Chebula extract on LPS-induced microglial inflammation.
results_summary: Terminalia Chebula extract significantly reduced pro-inflammatory factors (TNF-α, IL-1β, IL-6, PGE-2, COX-2) and nitric oxide levels while enhancing arginase-1 expression and urea production in LPS-induced microglial cells, demonstrating potent anti-inflammatory effects.
population_specificity: LPS-induced mice microglial cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Terminalia chebula extract (TCE) alleviates scopolamine-induced amnesia in mice and investigated potential mechanisms involving the cholinergic system and antioxidant effects.
results_summary: TCE reversed scopolamine-induced learning and memory deficits, reduced hippocampal AChE activity, increased ChAT and ACh levels, and suppressed oxidative damage by lowering ROS, NO, and MDA levels.
population_specificity: Mice with scopolamine-induced memory impairment

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the nephroprotective effect of Terminalia chebula hydroalcoholic extract against cisplatin-induced kidney damage in rats.
results_summary: Terminalia chebula extract significantly reduced serum creatinine, blood urea nitrogen, oxidative stress markers, and apoptotic markers in a dose-dependent manner, while also reversing histological kidney damage caused by cisplatin.
population_specificity: Wistar rats
effective_dosage: Different doses (specific amounts not stated in the abstract) administered orally

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the in vitro antibacterial activity of Terminalia chebula extract against microorganisms causing bovine subclinical mastitis.
results_summary: The ethyl acetate extract of Terminalia chebula demonstrated antimicrobial activity against all tested isolates, with 500 µg/mL concentration being as effective as standard amoxicillin. The study supports its potential as an alternative to antibiotic therapy for bovine subclinical mastitis.
population_specificity: Cattle (Kankrej, Gir, and Crossbred breeds) with subclinical mastitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the acute and repeated dose oral toxicity of a hydrolysable tannin-rich fraction (HTF) from Terminalia chebula in Wistar albino rats.
results_summary: HTF showed no acute toxicity at 5000 mg/kg but caused mild liver and kidney disturbances at 1000 mg/kg over 28 days, including reduced body weight, food/water intake, and altered serum parameters. Histopathology revealed mild liver inflammation but no abnormalities in other organs.
population_specificity: Wistar albino rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the toxicity of Terminalia chebula fruit extract (TCF) and its bioactive constituent 7-Methyl gallic acid (7MG) under in vitro and in vivo conditions to assess safety for potential clinical use.
results_summary: The study found no cytotoxic, genotoxic, hemolytic, or mutagenic effects of TCF and 7MG up to 2000 μg/ml in vitro, and no adverse changes in body weight, behavior, hematology, or organ histopathology in vivo, concluding they are relatively non-toxic.
population_specificity: In vitro (PBMC, RBC) and in vivo (animal models, species not specified)
effective_dosage: 250-2000 μg/ml (in vitro); exact in vivo dosage not specified
study_duration: Acute and subacute toxicity study durations not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effects of Terminalia chebula fruit extract against diazinon-induced oxidative stress and liver dysfunction in rats.
results_summary: Terminalia chebula extract significantly improved liver antioxidant markers (CAT, SOD, vitamin C, HDL) and reduced oxidative stress markers (MDA, PC, TG, TC, VLDL, TNF-α) compared to untreated diazinon-exposed rats. Histopathological findings also showed reduced liver lymphocyte infiltration.
population_specificity: Wistar rats administered diazinon (25 mg/kg body weight).
effective_dosage: 200, 400, and 800 mg/kg body weight of Terminalia chebula extract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the anticholinesterase and antioxidant activities of Terminalia chebula fruit extract (TCEA) for potential use in Alzheimer's disease treatment.
results_summary: TCEA exhibited potent acetylcholinesterase (AChE) and butyrylcholinesterase (BuChE) inhibitory activities comparable to donepezil, along with strong antioxidant properties, including free radical scavenging and metal-chelating activities. The bioactive compound methyl N-(N-benzyloxycarbonyl-beta-l-aspartyl)-beta-d-glucosaminide was identified as a key contributor to these effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and in silico study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the cytotoxic potential of chebulinic acid, a component of Terminalia chebula, in human myeloid leukemia cells, particularly its ability to induce apoptosis.
results_summary: Chebulinic acid selectively induced apoptosis in acute promyelocytic leukemia HL-60 and NB4 cells but not K562 cells, involving caspase activation, mitochondrial membrane changes, and extracellular signal-regulated kinases (ERK) activation. Inhibition of ERK mitigated the apoptosis, indicating a mechanism-dependent effect.
population_specificity: Human myeloid leukemia cell lines (HL-60, NB4, K562)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a standardized aqueous extract of Terminalia chebula fruit (AyuFlex®) on joint mobility, comfort, and functional capacity in healthy overweight subjects.
results_summary: AyuFlex® significantly improved joint health and function scores (mKOOS, mWOMAC), reduced knee discomfort during activity, enhanced whole-body joint function, and improved 6-min walk test performance, with no reported adverse effects. Both doses (250 mg and 500 mg twice daily) showed efficacy, with minimal differences between them.
population_specificity: Overweight, apparently healthy male and female subjects (35-70 years) with knee discomfort during activity/exercise.
effective_dosage: 250 mg or 500 mg twice daily (AyuFlex1 and AyuFlex2, respectively).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the hypo-testicular activity of Terminalia chebula (fruit) extract, both alone and in combination with Musa balbisiana (seed) extract, compared to cyproterone acetate (CPA), for potential use as a polyherbal contraceptive.
results_summary: Terminalia chebula significantly reduced spermatogenic and androgenic activity, with effects comparable to CPA. The composite formulation ('Contracept-TM') showed stronger hypo-testicular effects than individual extracts, alongside elevated oxidative stress markers.
population_specificity: Rats (dose-adjusted by body weight)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the larvicidal and ovicidal activities of Terminalia chebula extracts against three mosquito species (Anopheles stephensi, Aedes aegypti, and Culex quinquefasciatus).
results_summary: The methanol extract of Terminalia chebula showed the highest larvicidal and ovicidal activity, with LC50 values ranging from 87.13 to 111.98 ppm for larvae and 100% egg mortality at 300 ppm. All solvent extracts demonstrated moderate effects, with efficacy increasing with concentration.
population_specificity: Mosquito larvae and eggs of Anopheles stephensi, Aedes aegypti, and Culex quinquefasciatus.
study_duration: 24 hours for larvicidal activity, 48 hours for ovicidal activity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the neuroprotective effects and mechanisms of Terminalia chebula extracts and ellagic acid against beta-amyloid-induced toxicity in PC12 cells.
results_summary: Methanolic and water extracts of Terminalia chebula and ellagic acid showed strong neuroprotective activity against Aβ25-35-induced PC12 cell damage at 0.5-5.0 μg/ml, reducing ROS production and calcium ion influx. Ellagic acid also exhibited partial neuroprotection against H2O2-induced damage.
population_specificity: Undifferentiated pheochromocytoma (PC12) cell line.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effect of Terminalia chebula alcoholic extract (TCAE) against oxidative cell death induced by quinolinic acid (QA) in PC12 and OLN-93 cells.
results_summary: TCAE at concentrations above 25μg/mL significantly increased cell viability and reduced oxidative stress markers (ROS, lipid peroxidation, and DNA damage) induced by QA. The extract showed no toxic effects at tested concentrations (6.25-50μg/mL).
population_specificity: PC12 (rat adrenal pheochromocytoma) and OLN-93 (rat oligodendrocyte) cell lines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of Terminalia Chebula aqueous extract rinse on Streptococcus mutans count compared to Triphala and its other constituents.
results_summary: Terminalia Chebula was effective in reducing S. mutans CFUs, though Triphala showed greater efficacy. The reduction was significant at 5 and 60 minutes post-rinse.
population_specificity: Subjects aged 15-40 years visiting the Department of Public Health Dentistry.
study_duration: Salivary samples were collected at 5 and 60 minutes post-rinse.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antibiofilm efficacy of a gallotannin from Terminalia chebula fruits, alone and in combination with gentamicin and trimethoprim, against multidrug-resistant uropathogenic E. coli biofilms.
results_summary: The gallotannin alone showed >50% antibiofilm efficacy after 24 hours, while combinations with gentamicin and trimethoprim achieved 71.24% and 93.4% efficacy, respectively, demonstrating synergistic interactions.
population_specificity: Multidrug-resistant uropathogenic E. coli isolates forming biofilms.
interactions: Synergistic interactions with gentamicin and trimethoprim noted.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the preventive effects of an ethanol extract of Terminalia chebula (EETC) on dental plaque bacteria-induced inflammation and bone resorption.
results_summary: EETC suppressed oral bacterial growth, reduced inflammatory cytokines and proteases, and inhibited osteoclast formation and bone resorption. It also abolished PGE2 and COX-2 expression and prevented matrix damage.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or cell culture study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and tolerability of Terminalia chebula in reducing serum uric acid levels in hyperuricemic subjects compared to febuxostat and placebo.
results_summary: Terminalia chebula 500 mg BID significantly reduced serum uric acid levels by 4 weeks (P<0.01), though less effectively than Terminalia bellerica 500 mg. All formulations were well tolerated.
population_specificity: 110 subjects with hyperuricemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antiviral activity of Terminalia chebula extract and its purified compounds (chebulagic acid and chebulinic acid) against HSV-2, comparing their efficacy to acyclovir.
results_summary: Terminalia chebula extract and its purified compounds demonstrated potent direct antiviral activity against HSV-2, effectively inhibiting virus attachment and penetration to host cells, though acyclovir was more effective in post-infection virus replication.
population_specificity: In vitro study using Vero cells (a monkey kidney cell line).
effective_dosage: Extract (IC50 = 0.01 μg/ml), chebulagic acid (IC50 = 1.41 μg/ml), chebulinic acid (IC50 = 0.06 μg/ml).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anticancer activity of homeopathic preparations of Terminalia chebula (TC) against breast cancer and evaluate their nanoparticulate nature.
results_summary: The study found that Terminalia chebula preparations (MT, 3X, 6C, and 30C) reduced the viability and growth kinetics of breast cancer cells (MDAMB231 and MCF7) while sparing non-cancerous cells (HEK 293). Nanoparticles were detected in MT and 6C preparations.
population_specificity: Breast cancer cell lines (MDAMB231 and MCF7) and non-cancerous cell line (HEK 293).
effective_dosage: Mother tincture (MT), 3X, 6C, and 30C potencies, tested at 1:10 dilution.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the toxicity effects of different gall extracts of Terminalia chebula using the Brine shrimp (Artemia salina) toxicity assay and correlate these effects with phytochemical content.
results_summary: The study found that ethanol extract of T. chebula was highly toxic to brine shrimp (LC50 = 68.64 μg/ml), while petroleum ether and chloroform extracts showed low toxicity. The higher toxicity of ethanol extract correlated with its higher phenolic and flavonoid content.
population_specificity: Brine shrimp (Artemia salina) nauplii.
effective_dosage: LC50 values: petroleum ether (4356.76 μg/ml), chloroform (1462.2 μg/ml), ethanol (68.64 μg/ml).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential of Terminalia Chebula as a therapeutic alternative for Alzheimer's disease by examining its biochemical constituents and effects on acetylcholinesterase inhibition, antioxidant activity, and anti-inflammatory properties.
results_summary: The review found that Terminalia Chebula extracts and its constituents exhibit acetylcholinesterase inhibitory, antioxidant, and anti-inflammatory effects, which are relevant to Alzheimer's disease treatment. The study suggests it may be a promising therapeutic alternative.
population_specificity: Not specified (literature review of existing studies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify Terminalia Chebula's potential as a lactate efflux inhibitor and its effects on monocarboxylate transporters, cancer cell viability, growth, and apoptosis in neuroblastoma.
results_summary: Terminalia Chebula extract (TCE) was the most potent lactate efflux inhibitor among 900 tested extracts, significantly reducing MCT1, MCT3, MCT4, and CD147 expression. It demonstrated selective cytotoxicity, growth inhibition, and apoptosis induction in neuroblastoma cells at low concentrations.
population_specificity: Neuroblastoma (N2-A) cell line and DI-TNC1 primary cell line.
effective_dosage: IC50 values: 3.59 ± 0.26 μg/ml (N2-A), 7.37 ± 0.28 μg/ml (DI-TNC1); apoptosis induced at 7.5 μg/ml.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the in vitro antibacterial activity of methyl gallate (MG) isolated from Terminalia chebula against multidrug-resistant Shigella spp.
results_summary: MG demonstrated strong bactericidal activity against multidrug-resistant Shigella spp., causing membrane disintegration and cytoplasmic leakage. It also showed significant intracellular activity, reducing viable Shigella dysenteriae to zero within 20 hours at 4×MBC concentration.
population_specificity: In vitro study using bacterial cultures (Shigella spp.) and HeLa cell cultures.
effective_dosage: 4×MBC (minimal bactericidal concentration) for time-kill kinetic studies.
study_duration: Up to 24 hours for cellular drug accumulation; 20 hours for time-kill kinetics.

study_goal: To investigate the anti-inflammatory effects of Coptis chinensis plus myrobalan (CM) in vitro and in vivo.
results_summary: CM significantly promoted macrophage growth and phagocytosis, inhibited overproduction of inflammatory markers (NO, iNOS, TNF-α, IL-6), and reduced ear swelling and paw edema in mice, with high-dose CM outperforming dexamethasone.
population_specificity: Mouse peritoneal macrophages and mouse models of inflammation.
effective_dosage: 150-18.75 μg·mL(-1) in vitro; dose-dependent in vivo (specific doses not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the chemical composition and free radical scavenging potential of Terminalia Chebula leaf gall extracts to assess its antioxidant properties.
results_summary: The ethanolic extract showed the highest antioxidant activity, correlating with its high phenolic and flavonoid content, supporting its traditional use as a natural antioxidant. The study confirmed its potential for medicinal, functional food, and nutraceutical applications.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the anti-hyperlipidemic properties of a methanol bark extract of Terminalia chebula in diet-induced hypercholesterolemic animals.
results_summary: The methanol extract of T. chebula bark significantly lowered serum cholesterol and triglyceride levels and increased HDL cholesterol levels in hypercholesterolemic animals, comparable to the positive control atorvastatin. Acute toxicity studies showed no morbidity or mortality at tested doses.
population_specificity: Diet-induced hypercholesterolemic animals (species not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate chebulagic acid (CHA) from Terminalia chebula for its effects on PPARγ signaling, adipogenesis, glucose transport, and adipocyte endocrine function, comparing it to the synthetic drug rosiglitazone.
results_summary: CHA moderately enhanced PPARγ signaling and adipogenesis, increased GLUT4 expression and adiponectin secretion, and upregulated the PPARγ target gene C/EBP-α, behaving like a partial PPARγ agonist with potential for T2DM treatment.
population_specificity: In vitro adipocyte model (not specified if human or animal-derived).
effective_dosage: Dose-dependent effects noted, but specific amounts not provided.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the antimicrobial properties of Terminalia chebula against oral pathogens related to caries.
results_summary: The study found that Terminalia chebula extract had significant antimicrobial activity against oral pathogens, with a gradual increase in salivary pH post-rinse and a reduction in microbial load. The extract also contained notable levels of phenols and flavonoids.
population_specificity: Twenty high caries risk patients.
study_duration: Single rinse, effects measured up to 45 minutes post-rinse.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Terminalia chebula extract (WETC) could inhibit death receptor-mediated cell death (necroptosis and apoptosis) and explore its underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: WETC was found to be a potent dual inhibitor of necroptosis and apoptosis, suppressing TNF-induced ROS and inhibiting the caspase cascade. It also activated autophagy via mTOR suppression, with punicalagin and geraniin identified as key active constituents.
population_specificity: In vitro cellular models (specific cell type not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the curative effect and mechanism of action of Terminalia chebula polyphenolic extracts in reducing inflammation and morbidity caused by avian pathogenic Escherichia coli (APEC) in chickens.
results_summary: The extracts of Terminalia chebula reduced morbidity and inflammation in APEC-challenged chickens by reversing the overexpression of TLR genes, downregulating NF-kB pathways, and inhibiting pro-inflammatory cytokines. The study suggests Terminalia chebula may be a potential alternative treatment for avian colibacillosis.
population_specificity: Specific-pathogen-free white Leghorn chickens (males, 21 days old)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-inflammatory activity of twelve compounds isolated from Terminalia chebula, specifically their ability to inhibit iNOS and COX-2 in LPS-stimulated macrophages.
results_summary: Two gallotannins (chebulinic acid and 2,3,6-tri-O-galloyl-beta-D-glucose) and two triterpenoids (arjunic acid and arjunolic acid) significantly reduced nitric oxide production and decreased iNOS and COX-2 protein expressions in macrophages.
population_specificity: LPS-stimulated macrophages (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the anti-proliferative effects of Chebulagic acid (CA) from Terminalia chebula on retinoblastoma cells and its potential mechanisms of action.
results_summary: CA inhibited retinoblastoma cell proliferation in a dose-dependent manner, induced apoptosis via mitochondrial membrane potential modulation, activated caspase 3, and caused G1 arrest by increasing p27 expression. It also decreased NFκB levels in the nucleus by suppressing IκBα degradation.
population_specificity: Retinoblastoma cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the biocompatibility and bioactive effects of Terminalia chebula extracts on fibroblast and keratinocyte cells, focusing on wound healing applications and ammonia toxicity reduction.
results_summary: The study found that Terminalia chebula extracts reduced ammonia accumulation, demonstrated free-radical scavenging ability, and enhanced cell proliferation, cytoskeletal structure, and ECM production without harming normal cellular matrix. The effects were concentration-dependent.
population_specificity: In vitro study using fibroblast (L929) and keratinocyte cells.
effective_dosage: Different concentrations of organic and aqueous extracts (specific amounts not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Terminalia chebula ethanol extract in treating hot water-induced burn wounds in rats and compare it with silver sulfadiazine (SSD).
results_summary: Terminalia chebula 10% cream showed better wound contraction and lower wound size compared to SSD1% and control groups by day 10, with improved scar strength and collagen formation by day 15.
population_specificity: Rats with hot water-induced burn wounds.
effective_dosage: 5% and 10% T. chebula extracts applied topically.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a 10% Terminalia chebula mouth rinse compared to chlorhexidine 0.12% and saline in reducing dental plaque and gingivitis.
results_summary: Terminalia chebula mouth rinse significantly reduced microbial plaque, gingival inflammation, and neutralized salivary pH, with comparable efficacy to chlorhexidine and no significant difference between the two treatments.
population_specificity: 78 patients with dental plaque and gingivitis.
effective_dosage: 10% Terminalia chebula mouth rinse, applied two times daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antitussive effects of Terminalia chebula on SO2-induced cough in mice and assess its safety profile, including LD50 and neurotoxicity.
results_summary: Terminalia chebula dose-dependently suppressed SO2-induced cough in mice, with 500 mg/kg showing maximum efficacy comparable to codeine and dextromethorphan. The LD50 was approximately 1265 mg/kg, and no neurotoxicity was observed at antitussive doses, suggesting partial opioid receptor involvement in its mechanism.
population_specificity: Mice (animal study)
interactions: Naloxone partially reversed the antitussive effect, while rimcazole did not. No other interactions mentioned.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, anti-lipid peroxidative, and membrane-stabilizing effects of Terminalia chebula fruit extract and establish a possible association between these effects.
results_summary: The study found that Terminalia chebula extract significantly reduced inflammation (69.96% reduction in rat paw edema), protected human RBC membrane stability (96.72%), and demonstrated strong antioxidant activity (IC50 42.14 µg/ml in DPPH assay). The extract also contained high phenolic content (118.5 mg gallic acid equivalent/g).
population_specificity: Rats (in vivo) and human erythrocytes (in vitro)
effective_dosage: 50-500 mg/kg (in vivo), 50-500 µg/ml (in vitro), with 250 mg/kg being a key effective dose

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compile updated information on the phytochemistry, pharmacological properties, and therapeutic effectiveness of Terminalia chebula Retz.
results_summary: The study highlights Terminalia chebula's broad pharmacological activities, including antioxidant, antimicrobial, antidiabetic, hepatoprotective, and anti-inflammatory effects, but notes a lack of systematic data on its therapeutic effectiveness.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human use implied)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to isolate and identify bioactive compounds from Terminalia chebula fruits effective against multidrug-resistant uropathogens and assess the influence of metal ions on their antibacterial activity.
results_summary: The study identified 1,2,6-tri-O-galloyl-β-D-glucopyranose as the bioactive compound responsible for antibacterial activity against multidrug-resistant uropathogens, showing synergy with trimethoprim and gentamicin. The antibacterial effect was counteracted by iron supplementation.
population_specificity: Multidrug-resistant uropathogens (bacterial strains).
interactions: Synergy with trimethoprim and gentamicin; activity counteracted by iron.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-quorum sensing (anti-QS) potential of Terminalia Chebula Retz. fruit extract against Pseudomonas aeruginosa PAO1 and identify the compounds responsible for this activity.
results_summary: The methanol extract of T. chebula significantly reduced QS-regulated virulence factors, biofilm formation, and alginate production in P. aeruginosa PAO1, while enhancing susceptibility to tobramycin. The bioactive fraction (F7) downregulated key QS genes and reduced AHL production, leading to attenuated virulence and improved survival in C. elegans.
population_specificity: Pseudomonas aeruginosa PAO1 and C. elegans (in vivo model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the molecular mechanisms and protein expression changes induced by Terminalia Chebula extract in Jurkat cells, focusing on its potential antitumor effects.
results_summary: The study found that Terminalia Chebula extract significantly down-regulated specific proteins (β-tubulin, ring finger and CHY zinc finger domain containing 1, and insulin-like growth factor 1 receptor kinase) and inhibited nuclear factor-κB activity in Jurkat cells, suggesting potential antitumor effects.
population_specificity: Jurkat cells (a human T lymphocyte cell line)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate Terminalia Chebula's iron chelating properties and its potential to mitigate hepatic injury in iron-overloaded mice.
results_summary: The extract demonstrated significant iron chelation, DNA protection, and reduced hepatic damage markers, antioxidant enzyme restoration, and lowered lipid peroxidation in iron-overloaded mice. The 200 mg/kg dose showed the most pronounced effects.
population_specificity: Swiss Albino mice with induced iron overload.
effective_dosage: 50, 100, and 200 mg/kg body weight of TCME.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antilithiatic properties of Terminalia chebula, specifically its ability to inhibit calcium oxalate crystal nucleation and growth, as well as its cytoprotective effects on renal epithelial cells.
results_summary: Terminalia chebula aqueous extract showed 95.84% inhibition of calcium oxalate nucleation at 25µg/mL and dose-dependent inhibition of crystal growth. It also protected renal epithelial cells from oxalate-induced injury, increasing cell viability and reducing lactate dehydrogenase release in a concentration-dependent manner.
population_specificity: In vitro study using NRK-52E and MDCK renal epithelial cells.
effective_dosage: 25µg/mL and higher concentrations (exact upper limit not specified).
study_duration: 48 hours for cell injury experiments (other durations not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-arthritic and analgesic effects of NDI10218, a standardized ethanol extract of Terminalia chebula, in collagen-induced arthritis and acetic acid-induced writhing models.
results_summary: NDI10218 reduced arthritis severity, synovial hyperplasia, and pro-inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IL-6, IL-1β, IL-17) in mice, while also demonstrating analgesic effects in the writhing model. The extract also decreased T cell subpopulations in lymph nodes.
population_specificity: DBA/1J mice with collagen-induced arthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the pharmacological action of aqueous extract of Terminalia chebula seeds (ATC) on ileal motility and its effectiveness in relieving morphine-induced constipation.
results_summary: ATC increased ileum motility frequency and contraction tension dose-dependently, likely mediated through Ca²⁺ channel activation. It also improved fecal output and water content in morphine-induced constipation.
population_specificity: Rat ileum tissue and morphine-induced constipation model in rats.
